The Charles Center Project

The Wallace team proposed a single,
dramatic project that would reverse the
downslide. The proposal for the 33 acre
Charles Center project, located north and
west of the Inner Harbor, between the
retail and financial districts, was completed
in 1958 and presented to Mayor Thomas J.
D’Alesandro, Jr. The plan was received with
enthusiasm and turned over to the Balti-
more Urban Renewal and Housing agency
for detailed review and a feasibility study.
In March, 1959, the City Council adopted
Charles Center as an official urban renewal
plan.

The Charles Center plan’s adoption in
1959 effectively made the city government
and the downtown business community
partners, with a shared objective. This part-
nership was formalized in 1959 with the
establishment of the Charles Center Man-
agement Office, led by ). Jefferson Miller,
to implement the project under a personal
contract with the city. The creation of this
office was a major factor in the speed with
which private developers were persuaded
to invest in the project. Through this man-
agement office the City could combine the
flexibility of a private corporation with the
city’s powers to raise working capital and
assemble land through emminent domain.

e

Inner Harbor Initiative

Construction was well underway at
Charles Center when Mayor Theodore R.
McKeldin, Jr., sounded the charge for Balti-
more to take its next big step forward: re-
claiming the Inner Harbor. In his inaugural
address on May 21, 1963, McKeldin talked
of an “enthralling panorama of office build-
ings, parks, high-rise apartments, and mari-
nas’’ around the old harbor. He urged that
a plan be developed for the area, consist-
ing of 240 acres including the financial and
municipal districts, adjacent to the still-
developing Charles Center Project.

At the time of Mayor McKeldin’s call,
the Inner Harbor had already been partially
cleaned up. Beginning in 1950 under
Mayor D’Alesandro, Jr., the piers and
decayed structures at the west end of the
Inner Harbor along Light Street had been

‘removed.

The Planning Council was again com-
missioned to prepare a proposal and David
Wallace’s firm, Wallace-McHarg of Phila-
delphia, was hired. Funding for this step
was an arrangement involving three
groups, with $35,000 provided by the city
and $25,000 each from the Greater Balti-
more Committee and Committee for
Downtown. This three member partnership
was an important step in Baltimore’s move
toward increased government initiative in
the redevelopment process.

The conceptual plan that was pro-
duced a year later, while it has been

Harbor skyline, view north from Key Highway



altered in particulars, has provided the
basic guidance for the redevelopment that
constitutes today’s Inner Harbor area. The
spirit of the 1964 plan was described this
way:

“This historic spot, its basin and its
shorelines, can become the stage for a
dramatic exercise in urban renewal.
Now the scene of run-down docks,
wharves, and with few exceptions,
economically unsound enterprises, the
.Inner Harbor emerges as a candidate
for the best use of water and open
land in post-war U.S. urban renewal.
Instead of cutting the water off from
the city as almost all our cities do, Bal-
timore will thrust the living, 24-hour-a-
day city into intimate, vivacious contact
with the harbor whence it sprang.

In the place of the old piers, multi-lane
expansions of Calvert and Light Streets had
been built in the early 1950’s with parking
lots directly on the water and a small patch
of green space at the intersection of Light
and Pratt Streets, known as Sam Smith Park.
The widened roadway had been built on
fill at the western edge of the harbor
where the steamships had once docked.
The transformation had begun. However,
the western edge of the water was given
over entirely to vehicles, and the obsolete
structures which remained at the north and
south sides of the harbor, many in poor
condition, still constituted a barrier to pub-
lic use of the area. There were no provi-
sions for access to the shoreline and no
attractions to draw people to the still pol-
luted water’s edge.

The 1964 plan called for a 30-year, $260-
million effort along the harbor’s edge and
in the adjacent financial and municipal dis-
tricts. Over 700 pieces of property were
involved. The city was fortunate to already
own the key, 18-acre waterfront along Pratt
and Light Streets which was purchased after
the 1904 fire and expanded by fill in the
early 1950’s.

In 1964 the voters authorized $2 mil-
lion in bonds to finance the first steps in
redevelopment of the Inner Harbor, less
than 10 years after the first concerted action
had been taken in Charles Center to re-
verse downtown Baltimore’s decline.

Another aspect of the 1964 plan is
worth noting. It called for opening the
harbor’s edge to the public. And while it
seems a natural recommendation to us
today, it should be remembered that in
1964 waterfronts were usually ignored and
were often proposed for highways. As late
as 1968, there were still plans for a super-
highway along Montgomery Street and the
base of Federal Hill with a bridge over the
Harbor which would have cut off the Har-
bor basin from the rest of the City.
